Negligence

Negligence is defined as the failure to comply with a policy, regulation, code or statute. It can also be an unintentional ‘tort’ - a behaviour or action that falls below a reasonable standard of care. A person is negligent when they act in a manner that is not reasonable or consistent with prudence and care. It can include ‘wrongful acts’ – errors, omissions, actions or decisions that harm others or expose others to unreasonable risk of harm.

 

Negligence could be claimed when CAF members knowingly (or recklessly) expose others to significant hazards without taking reasonable measures to ensure their well-being.

 

For example, leaving ammunition in an unlocked vehicle in plain sight of passers-by could be seen as being negligent.
